instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: A1466 Doesn't Boot - Stuck Apple Logo
threads.message:
A1466 Doesn't Boot - Stuck Apple Logo 

Cant get into recovery, bootable drives don't work , 

Tried multiple known good SSD's

Any idea?

threads.title: A1466 Doesn't Boot - Stuck Apple Logo
threads.message:
Try new BIOS, wirh clean ME.
Upload backup and post model board.

threads.title: A1466 Doesn't Boot - Stuck Apple Logo
threads.message:
"Try ne BIOS, wirh clean ME."

I have not done this before -- is there a guide with the process that I can refer to?  Quick google research I see I can access the bios by holding “Command,” “Option,” “0” and “F” on boot.

threads.title: A1466 Doesn't Boot - Stuck Apple Logo
threads.message:
Means you need to remove SPI chip (U6100) and reprogram it with external programmer, like TL866, CH341, or similar.
I suppose you don't have Medusa 2, which can do all the job onboard...

threads.title: A1466 Doesn't Boot - Stuck Apple Logo
threads.message:
Should I get a Medusa 2? 

More than happy to buy one if its a must have .. where do you recommend I order it from?

threads.title: A1466 Doesn't Boot - Stuck Apple Logo
threads.message:
It is, if you plan to work more time with Apple stuff.
[URL]http://www.cmizapper.com/products/medusa-2.html[/URL]

threads.title: A1466 Doesn't Boot - Stuck Apple Logo
threads.message:
Thank you.

One more question, can I replace the SPI chip (U6100) with one from a donor board? Would that work or are they somehow married to the logic board?

threads.title: A1466 Doesn't Boot - Stuck Apple Logo
threads.message:
Usually serves for test.
But it will have "dirty" ME region, because comes from other board.
However this way cannot completely discard BIOS issue.
If board starts, 100% is BIOS.
If not, doesn't mean old BIOS is OK.

threads.title: A1466 Doesn't Boot - Stuck Apple Logo
threads.message: If it starts , what would be the negative side effects of running with a "dirty" ME region?

threads.title: A1466 Doesn't Boot - Stuck Apple Logo
threads.message:
If it starts, don't even think to use it with that ME region.
You can swap your ME region on it.
As Fsys area and serial number too.
